Technician.question: Which of the following is part of the Basis and Purpose of the Amateur Radio Service?
Technician.answer: Advancing skills in the technical and communication phases of the radio art

Technician.question: Which agency regulates and enforces the rules for the Amateur Radio Service in the United States?
What do the FCC rules state regarding the use of a phonetic alphabet for station identification in the Amateur Radio Service?
How many operator/primary station license grants may be held by any one person?
What proves that the FCC has issued an operator/primary license grant?
Technician.answer: The license appears in the FCC ULS database

Technician.question: What is the FCC Part 97 definition of a beacon?
Technician.answer: An amateur station transmitting communications for the purposes of observing propagation or related experimental activities

Technician.question: What is the FCC Part 97 definition of a space station?
Technician.answer: An amateur station located more than 50 km above Earth's surface

Technician.question: Which of the following entities recommends transmit/receive channels and other parameters for auxiliary and repeater stations?
Technician.answer: Volunteer Frequency Coordinator recognized by local amateurs

Technician.question: Who selects a Frequency Coordinator?
Technician.answer: Amateur operators in a local or regional area whose stations are eligible to be repeater or auxiliary stations

Technician.question: What is the Radio Amateur Civil Emergency Service (RACES)?
When is willful interference to other amateur radio stations permitted?
Which of the following frequency ranges are available for phone operation by Technician licensees?
Which amateurs may contact the International Space Station (ISS) on VHF bands?
Technician.answer: Any amateur holding a Technician class or higher license

Technician.question: Which frequency is in the 6 meter amateur band?
Which amateur band includes 146.52 MHz?
How may amateurs use the 219 to 220 MHz segment of 1.25 meter band?
Technician.answer: Fixed digital message forwarding systems only

Technician.question: On which HF bands does a Technician class operator have phone privileges?
Which of the following VHF/UHF band segments are limited to CW only?
Technician.answer: 50.0 MHz to 50.1 MHz and 144.0 MHz to 144.1 MHz

Technician.question: How are US amateurs restricted in segments of bands where the Amateur Radio Service is secondary?
Technician.answer: U.S. amateurs may find non-amateur stations in those segments, and must avoid interfering with them

Technician.question: Why should you not set your transmit frequency to be exactly at the edge of an amateur band or sub-band?
Where may SSB phone be used in amateur bands above 50 MHz?
Technician.answer: In at least some segment of all these bands

Technician.question: What is the maximum peak envelope power output for Technician class operators in their HF band segments?
Except for some specific restrictions, what is the maximum peak envelope power output for Technician class operators using frequencies above 30 MHz?
For which license classes are new licenses currently available from the FCC?
Who may select a desired call sign under the vanity call sign rules?
What types of international communications are an FCC-licensed amateur radio station permitted to make?
Technician.answer: Communications incidental to the purposes of the Amateur Radio Service and remarks of a personal character

Technician.question: What may happen if the FCC is unable to reach you by email?
Technician.answer: Revocation of the station license or suspension of the operator license

Technician.question: Which of the following is a valid Technician class call sign format?
From which of the following locations may an FCC-licensed amateur station transmit?
Technician.answer: From any vessel or craft located in international waters and documented or registered in the United States

Technician.question: Which of the following can result in revocation of the station license or suspension of the operator license?
Technician.answer: Failure to provide and maintain a correct email address with the FCC

Technician.question: What is the normal term for an FCC-issued amateur radio license?
What is the grace period for renewal if an amateur license expires?
How soon after passing the examination for your first amateur radio license may you transmit on the amateur radio bands?
Technician.answer: As soon as your operator/station license grant appears in the FCC’s license database

Technician.question: If your license has expired and is still within the allowable grace period, may you continue to transmit on the amateur radio bands?
Technician.answer: No, you must wait until the license has been renewed

Technician.question: With which countries are FCC-licensed amateur radio stations prohibited from exchanging communications?
Technician.answer: Any country whose administration has notified the International Telecommunication Union (ITU) that it objects to such communications

Technician.question: Under which of the following circumstances are one-way transmissions by an amateur station prohibited?
When is it permissible to transmit messages encoded to obscure their meaning?
Technician.answer: Only when transmitting control commands to space stations or radio control craft

Technician.question: Under what conditions is an amateur station authorized to transmit music using a phone emission?
Technician.answer: When incidental to an authorized retransmission of manned spacecraft communications

Technician.question: When may amateur radio operators use their stations to notify other amateurs of the availability of equipment for sale or trade?
Technician.answer: When selling amateur radio equipment and not on a regular basis

Technician.question: What, if any, are the restrictions concerning transmission of language that may be considered indecent or obscene?
What types of amateur stations can automatically retransmit the signals of other amateur stations?
In which of the following circumstances may the control operator of an amateur station receive compensation for operating that station?
Technician.answer: When the communication is incidental to classroom instruction at an educational institution

Technician.question: When may amateur stations transmit information in support of broadcasting, program production, or news gathering, assuming no other means is available?
Technician.answer: When such communications are directly related to the immediate safety of human life or protection of property

Technician.question: How does the FCC define broadcasting for the Amateur Radio Service?
Technician.answer: Transmissions intended for reception by the general public

Technician.question: When may an amateur station transmit without identifying on the air?
Technician.answer: When transmitting signals to control model craft

Technician.question: When may an amateur station transmit without a control operator?
Who may be the control operator of a station communicating through an amateur satellite or space station?
Technician.answer: Any amateur allowed to transmit on the satellite uplink frequency

Technician.question: Who must designate the station control operator?
What determines the transmitting frequency privileges of an amateur station?
Technician.answer: The class of operator license held by the control operator

Technician.question: What is an amateur station control point?
Technician.answer: The location at which the control operator function is performed

Technician.question: When, under normal circumstances, may a Technician class licensee be the control operator of a station operating in an Amateur Extra Class band segment?
When the control operator is not the station licensee, who is responsible for the proper operation of the station?
Technician.answer: The control operator and the station licensee

Technician.question: Which of the following is an example of automatic control?
Which of the following are required for remote control operation?
Which of the following is an example of remote control as defined in Part 97?
Technician.answer: Operating the station over the internet

Technician.question: Who does the FCC presume to be the control operator of an amateur station, unless documentation to the contrary is in the station records?
When must the station and its records be available for FCC inspection?
Technician.answer: At any time upon request by an FCC representative

Technician.question: How often must you identify with your FCC-assigned call sign when using tactical call signs such as “Race Headquarters”?
Technician.answer: At the end of each communication and every ten minutes during a communication

Technician.question: When are you required to transmit your assigned call sign?
Technician.answer: At least every 10 minutes during and at the end of a communication

Technician.question: What language may you use for identification when operating in a phone sub-band?
What method of call sign identification is required for a station transmitting phone signals?
Technician.answer: Send the call sign using a CW or phone emission

Technician.question: Which of the following self-assigned indicators are acceptable when using a phone transmission?
Which of the following restrictions apply when a non-licensed person is allowed to speak to a foreign station using a station under the control of a licensed amateur operator?
Technician.answer: The foreign station must be in a country with which the U.S. has a third party agreement

Technician.question: What is the definition of third party communications?
Technician.answer: A message from a control operator to another amateur station control operator on behalf of another person

Technician.question: What type of amateur station simultaneously retransmits the signal of another amateur station on a different channel or channels?
Who is accountable if a repeater inadvertently retransmits communications that violate the FCC rules?
Technician.answer: The control operator of the originating station

Technician.question: Which of the following is a requirement for the issuance of a club station license grant?
Technician.answer: The club must have at least four members

Technician.question: What is a common repeater frequency offset in the 2 meter band?
What is the national calling frequency for FM simplex operations in the 2 meter band?
What is a common repeater frequency offset in the 70 cm band?
What is an appropriate way to call another station on a repeater if you know the other station's call sign?
Technician.answer: Say the station's call sign, then identify with your call sign

Technician.question: How should you respond to a station calling CQ?
Technician.answer: Transmit the other station’s call sign followed by your call sign

Technician.question: Which of the following is required when making on-the-air test transmissions?
What is meant by "repeater offset"?
Technician.answer: The difference between a repeater’s transmit and receive frequencies

Technician.question: What is the meaning of the procedural signal “CQ”?
Which of the following indicates that a station is listening on a repeater and looking for a contact?
Technician.answer: The station’s call sign followed by the word "monitoring"

Technician.question: What is a band plan, beyond the privileges established by the FCC?
Technician.answer: A voluntary guideline for using different modes or activities within an amateur band

Technician.question: What term describes an amateur station that is transmitting and receiving on the same frequency?
What should you do before calling CQ?
How is a VHF/UHF transceiver’s “reverse” function used?
Technician.answer: To listen on a repeater’s input frequency

Technician.question: What term describes the use of a sub-audible tone transmitted along with normal voice audio to open the squelch of a receiver?
Which of the following describes a linked repeater network?
Technician.answer: A network of repeaters in which signals received by one repeater are transmitted by all the repeaters in the network

Technician.question: Which of the following could be the reason you are unable to access a repeater whose output you can hear?
What would cause your FM transmission audio to be distorted on voice peaks?
What type of signaling uses pairs of audio tones?
How can you join a digital repeater’s “talkgroup”?
Technician.answer: Program your radio with the group’s ID or code

Technician.question: Which of the following applies when two stations transmitting on the same frequency interfere with each other?
Technician.answer: The stations should negotiate continued use of the frequency

Technician.question: Why are simplex channels designated in the VHF/UHF band plans?
Technician.answer: So stations within range of each other can communicate without tying up a repeater

Technician.question: Which Q signal indicates that you are receiving interference from other stations?
Which Q signal indicates that you are changing frequency?
What is the purpose of the color code used on DMR repeater systems?
Technician.answer: Must match the repeater color code for access

Technician.question: What is the purpose of a squelch function?
Technician.answer: Mute the receiver audio when a signal is not present

Technician.question: When do FCC rules NOT apply to the operation of an amateur station?
Which of the following are typical duties of a Net Control Station?
Technician.answer: Call the net to order and direct communications between stations checking in

Technician.question: What technique is used to ensure that voice messages containing unusual words are received correctly?
Technician.answer: Spell the words using a standard phonetic alphabet

Technician.question: What is RACES?
Technician.answer: An FCC part 97 amateur radio service for civil defense communications during national emergencies

Technician.question: What does the term “traffic” refer to in net operation?
What is the Amateur Radio Emergency Service (ARES)?
Technician.answer: A group of licensed amateurs who have voluntarily registered their qualifications and equipment for communications duty in the public service

Technician.question: Which of the following is standard practice when you participate in a net?
Technician.answer: Unless you are reporting an emergency, transmit only when directed by the net control station

Technician.question: Which of the following is a characteristic of good traffic handling?
Are amateur station control operators ever permitted to operate outside the frequency privileges of their license class?
Technician.answer: Yes, but only in situations involving the immediate safety of human life or protection of property

Technician.question: What information is contained in the preamble of a formal traffic message?
Technician.answer: Information needed to track the message

Technician.question: What is meant by “check” in a radiogram header?
Technician.answer: The number of words or word equivalents in the text portion of the message

Technician.question: Why do VHF signal strengths sometimes vary greatly when the antenna is moved only a few feet?
Technician.answer: Multipath propagation cancels or reinforces signals

Technician.question: What is the effect of vegetation on UHF and microwave signals?
What antenna polarization is normally used for long-distance CW and SSB contacts on the VHF and UHF bands?
What happens when antennas at opposite ends of a VHF or UHF line of sight radio link are not using the same polarization?
When using a directional antenna, how might your station be able to communicate with a distant repeater if buildings or obstructions are blocking the direct line of sight path?
Technician.answer: Try to find a path that reflects signals to the repeater

Technician.question: What is the meaning of the term “picket fencing”?
Technician.answer: Rapid flutter on mobile signals due to multipath propagation

Technician.question: What weather condition might decrease range at microwave frequencies?
What is a likely cause of irregular fading of signals propagated by the ionosphere?
Technician.answer: Random combining of signals arriving via different paths

Technician.question: Which of the following results from the fact that signals propagated by the ionosphere are elliptically polarized?
Technician.answer: Either vertically or horizontally polarized antennas may be used for transmission or reception

Technician.question: What effect does multi-path propagation have on data transmissions?
Technician.answer: Error rates are likely to increase

Technician.question: Which region of the atmosphere can refract or bend HF and VHF radio waves?
What is the effect of fog and rain on signals in the 10 meter and 6 meter bands?
What is the relationship between the electric and magnetic fields of an electromagnetic wave?
What property of a radio wave defines its polarization?
Technician.answer: The orientation of the electric field

Technician.question: What are the two components of a radio wave?
What is the velocity of a radio wave traveling through free space?
What is the relationship between wavelength and frequency?
Technician.answer: Wavelength gets shorter as frequency increases

Technician.question: What is the formula for converting frequency to approximate wavelength in meters?
Technician.answer: Wavelength in meters equals 300 divided by frequency in megahertz

Technician.question: In addition to frequency, which of the following is used to identify amateur radio bands?
What frequency range is referred to as VHF?
What frequency range is referred to as UHF?
What frequency range is referred to as HF?
What is the approximate velocity of a radio wave in free space?
Why are simplex UHF signals rarely heard beyond their radio horizon?
Technician.answer: UHF signals are usually not propagated by the ionosphere

Technician.question: What is a characteristic of HF communication compared with communications on VHF and higher frequencies?
Technician.answer: Long-distance ionospheric propagation is far more common on HF

Technician.question: What is a characteristic of VHF signals received via auroral backscatter?
Technician.answer: They are distorted and signal strength varies considerably

Technician.question: Which of the following types of propagation is most commonly associated with occasional strong signals on the 10, 6, and 2 meter bands from beyond the radio horizon?
Which of the following effects may allow radio signals to travel beyond obstructions between the transmitting and receiving stations?
What type of propagation is responsible for allowing over-the-horizon VHF and UHF communications to ranges of approximately 300 miles on a regular basis?
What band is best suited for communicating via meteor scatter?
What causes tropospheric ducting?
What is generally the best time for long-distance 10 meter band propagation via the F region?
Technician.answer: From dawn to shortly after sunset during periods of high sunspot activity

Technician.question: Which of the following bands may provide long-distance communications via the ionosphere’s F region during the peak of the sunspot cycle?
Why is the radio horizon for VHF and UHF signals more distant than the visual horizon?
Technician.answer: The atmosphere refracts radio waves slightly

Technician.question: Which of the following is an appropriate power supply rating for a typical 50 watt output mobile FM transceiver?
Which of the following should be considered when selecting an accessory SWR meter?
Technician.answer: The frequency and power level at which the measurements will be made

Technician.question: Why are short, heavy-gauge wires used for a transceiver’s DC power connection?
Technician.answer: To minimize voltage drop when transmitting

Technician.question: How are the transceiver audio input and output connected in a station configured to operate using FT8?
Technician.answer: To the audio input and output of a computer running WSJT-X software

Technician.question: Where should an RF power meter be installed?
Technician.answer: In the feed line, between the transmitter and antenna

Technician.question: What signals are used in a computer-radio interface for digital mode operation?
Technician.answer: Receive audio, transmit audio, and transmitter keying

Technician.question: Which of the following connections is made between a computer and a transceiver to use computer software when operating digital modes?
Technician.answer: Computer “line in” to transceiver speaker connector

Technician.question: Which of the following conductors is preferred for bonding at RF?
How can you determine the length of time that equipment can be powered from a battery?
Technician.answer: Divide the battery ampere-hour rating by the average current draw of the equipment

Technician.question: What function is performed with a transceiver and a digital mode hot spot?
Technician.answer: Communication using digital voice or data systems via the internet

Technician.question: Where should the negative power return of a mobile transceiver be connected in a vehicle?
Technician.answer: At the 12 volt battery chassis ground

Technician.question: What is an electronic keyer?
Technician.answer: A device that assists in manual sending of Morse code

Technician.question: What is the effect of excessive microphone gain on SSB transmissions?
Which of the following can be used to enter a transceiver’s operating frequency?
How is squelch adjusted so that a weak FM signal can be heard?
Technician.answer: Set the squelch threshold so that receiver output audio is on all the time

Technician.question: What is a way to enable quick access to a favorite frequency or channel on your transceiver?
Technician.answer: Store it in a memory channel

Technician.question: What does the scanning function of an FM transceiver do?
Technician.answer: Tunes through a range of frequencies to check for activity

Technician.question: Which of the following controls could be used if the voice pitch of a single-sideband signal returning to your CQ call seems too high or low?
What does a DMR “code plug” contain?
Technician.answer: Access information for repeaters and talkgroups

Technician.question: What is the advantage of having multiple receive bandwidth choices on a multimode transceiver?
Technician.answer: Permits noise or interference reduction by selecting a bandwidth matching the mode

Technician.question: How is a specific group of stations selected on a digital voice transceiver?
Technician.answer: By entering the group's identification code

Technician.question: Which of the following receiver filter bandwidths provides the best signal-to-noise ratio for SSB reception?
Which of the following must be programmed into a D-STAR digital transceiver before transmitting?
What is the result of tuning an FM receiver above or below a signal's frequency?
Electrical current is measured in which of the following units?
Electrical power is measured in which of the following units?
What is the name for the flow of electrons in an electric circuit?
What are the units of electrical resistance?
What is the electrical term for the force that causes electron flow?
What is the unit of frequency?
Why are metals generally good conductors of electricity?
Which of the following is a good electrical insulator?
Which of the following describes alternating current?
Technician.answer: Current that alternates between positive and negative directions

Technician.question: Which term describes the rate at which electrical energy is used?
What type of current flow is opposed by resistance?
What describes the number of times per second that an alternating current makes a complete cycle?
How many milliamperes is 1.5 amperes?
Which is equal to 1,500,000 hertz?
Which is equal to one kilovolt?
Which is equal to one microvolt?
Which is equal to 500 milliwatts?
Which is equal to 3,000 milliamperes?
Which is equal to 3.525 MHz?
Which is equal to 1,000,000 picofarads?
Which decibel value most closely represents a power increase from 5 watts to 10 watts?
Which decibel value most closely represents a power decrease from 12 watts to 3 watts?
Which decibel value represents a power increase from 20 watts to 200 watts?
Which is equal to 28400 kHz?
Which is equal to 2425 MHz?
What describes the ability to store energy in an electric field?
What is the unit of capacitance?
What describes the ability to store energy in a magnetic field?
What is the unit of inductance?
What is the unit of impedance?
What does the abbreviation RF mean?
Technician.answer: Radio frequency signals of all types

Technician.question: What is the abbreviation for megahertz?
What is the formula used to calculate electrical power (P) in a DC circuit?
How much power is delivered by a voltage of 13.8 volts DC and a current of 10 amperes?
How much power is delivered by a voltage of 12 volts DC and a current of 2.5 amperes?
How much current is required to deliver 120 watts at a voltage of 12 volts DC?
What is impedance?
Technician.answer: The opposition to AC current flow

Technician.question: What is the abbreviation for kilohertz?
What formula is used to calculate current in a circuit?
What formula is used to calculate voltage in a circuit?
What formula is used to calculate resistance in a circuit?
What is the resistance of a circuit in which a current of 3 amperes flows when connected to 90 volts?
What is the resistance of a circuit for which the applied voltage is 12 volts and the current flow is 1.5 amperes?
What is the resistance of a circuit that draws 4 amperes from a 12-volt source?
What is the current in a circuit with an applied voltage of 120 volts and a resistance of 80 ohms?
What is the current through a 100-ohm resistor connected across 200 volts?
What is the current through a 24-ohm resistor connected across 240 volts?
What is the voltage across a 2-ohm resistor if a current of 0.5 amperes flows through it?
What is the voltage across a 10-ohm resistor if a current of 1 ampere flows through it?
What is the voltage across a 10-ohm resistor if a current of 2 amperes flows through it?
In which type of circuit is DC current the same through all components?
In which type of circuit is voltage the same across all components?
What electrical component opposes the flow of current in a DC circuit?
What type of component is often used as an adjustable volume control?
What electrical parameter is controlled by a potentiometer?
What electrical component stores energy in an electric field?
What type of electrical component consists of conductive surfaces separated by an insulator?
What type of electrical component stores energy in a magnetic field?
What electrical component is typically constructed as a coil of wire?
What is the function of an SPDT switch?
Technician.answer: A single circuit is switched between one of two other circuits

Technician.question: What electrical component is used to protect other circuit components from current overloads?
Which of the following battery chemistries is rechargeable?
Which of the following battery chemistries is not rechargeable?
What type of switch is represented by component 3 in figure T-2?
Which is true about forward voltage drop in a diode?
Technician.answer: It is lower in some diode types than in others

Technician.question: What electronic component allows current to flow in only one direction?
Which of these components can be used as an electronic switch?
Which of the following components can consist of three regions of semiconductor material?
What type of transistor has a gate, drain, and source?
How is the cathode lead of a semiconductor diode often marked on the package?
What causes a light-emitting diode (LED) to emit light?
What does the abbreviation FET stand for?
What are the names for the electrodes of a diode?
Which of the following can provide power gain?
What is the term that describes a device's ability to amplify a signal?
What are the names of the electrodes of a bipolar junction transistor?
What is the name of an electrical wiring diagram that uses standard component symbols?
What is component 1 in figure T1?
What is component 2 in figure T1?
What is component 3 in figure T1?
What is component 4 in figure T1?
What is component 6 in figure T2?
What is component 8 in figure T2?
What is component 9 in figure T2?
What is component 4 in figure T2?
What is component 3 in figure T3?
What is component 4 in figure T3?
Which of the following is accurately represented in electrical schematics?
Which of the following devices or circuits changes an alternating current into a varying direct current signal?
What is a relay?
Which of the following is a reason to use shielded wire?
Technician.answer: To prevent coupling of unwanted signals to or from the wire

Technician.question: Which of the following displays an electrical quantity as a numeric value?
What type of circuit controls the amount of voltage from a power supply?
What component changes 120 V AC power to a lower AC voltage for other uses?
Which of the following is commonly used as a visual indicator?
Which of the following is combined with an inductor to make a resonant circuit?
What is the name of a device that combines several semiconductors and other components into one package?
What is the function of component 2 in figure T-1?
Which of the following is a resonant or tuned circuit?
Technician.answer: An inductor and a capacitor in series or parallel

Technician.question: Which term describes the ability of a receiver to detect the presence of a signal?
What is a transceiver?
Technician.answer: A device that combines a receiver and transmitter

Technician.question: Which of the following is used to convert a signal from one frequency to another?
Which term describes the ability of a receiver to discriminate between multiple signals?
What is the name of a circuit that generates a signal at a specific frequency?
What device converts the RF input and output of a transceiver to another band?
What is the function of a transceiver's PTT input?
Technician.answer: Switches transceiver from receive to transmit when grounded

Technician.question: Which of the following describes combining speech with an RF carrier signal?
What is the function of the SSB/CW-FM switch on a VHF power amplifier?
Technician.answer: Set the amplifier for proper operation in the selected mode

Technician.question: What device increases the transmitted output power from a transceiver?
Where is an RF preamplifier installed?
What can you do if you are told your FM handheld or mobile transceiver is over-deviating?
Technician.answer: Talk farther away from the microphone

Technician.question: What would cause a broadcast AM or FM radio to receive an amateur radio transmission unintentionally?
Technician.answer: The receiver is unable to reject strong signals outside the AM or FM band

Technician.question: Which of the following can cause radio frequency interference?
Which of the following could you use to cure distorted audio caused by RF current on the shield of a microphone cable?
How can fundamental overload of a non-amateur radio or TV receiver by an amateur signal be reduced or eliminated?
Technician.answer: Block the amateur signal with a filter at the antenna input of the affected receiver

Technician.question: Which of the following actions should you take if a neighbor tells you that your station’s transmissions are interfering with their radio or TV reception?
Technician.answer: Make sure that your station is functioning properly and that it does not cause interference to your own radio or television when it is tuned to the same channel

Technician.question: Which of the following can reduce overload of a VHF transceiver by a nearby commercial FM station?
What should you do if something in a neighbor’s home is causing harmful interference to your amateur station?
What should be the first step to resolve non-fiber optic cable TV interference caused by your amateur radio transmission?
Technician.answer: Be sure all TV feed line coaxial connectors are installed properly

Technician.question: What might be a problem if you receive a report that your audio signal through an FM repeater is distorted or unintelligible?
What is a symptom of RF feedback in a transmitter or transceiver?
Technician.answer: Reports of garbled, distorted, or unintelligible voice transmissions

Technician.question: What is the primary purpose of a dummy load?
Technician.answer: To prevent transmitting signals over the air when making tests

Technician.question: Which of the following is used to determine if an antenna is resonant at the desired operating frequency?
What does a dummy load consist of?
Technician.answer: A non-inductive resistor mounted on a heat sink

Technician.question: What reading on an SWR meter indicates a perfect impedance match between the antenna and the feed line?
Why do most solid-state transmitters reduce output power as SWR increases beyond a certain level?
Technician.answer: To protect the output amplifier transistors

Technician.question: What does an SWR reading of 4:1 indicate?
What happens to power lost in a feed line?
Which instrument can be used to determine SWR?
Which of the following causes failure of coaxial cables?
Why should the outer jacket of coaxial cable be resistant to ultraviolet light?
Technician.answer: Ultraviolet light can damage the jacket and allow water to enter the cable

Technician.question: What is a disadvantage of air core coaxial cable when compared to foam or solid dielectric types?
Technician.answer: It requires special techniques to prevent moisture in the cable

Technician.question: Which instrument would you use to measure electric potential?
How is a voltmeter connected to a component to measure applied voltage?
When configured to measure current, how is a multimeter connected to a component?
Which instrument is used to measure electric current?
Which of the following can damage a multimeter?
Technician.answer: Attempting to measure voltage when using the resistance setting

Technician.question: Which of the following measurements are made using a multimeter?
Which of the following types of solder should not be used for radio and electronic applications?
What is the characteristic appearance of a cold tin-lead solder joint?
What reading indicates that an ohmmeter is connected across a large, discharged capacitor?
Which of the following precautions should be taken when measuring in-circuit resistance with an ohmmeter?
Technician.answer: Ensure that the circuit is not powered

Technician.question: Which of the following is a form of amplitude modulation?
What type of modulation is commonly used for VHF packet radio transmissions?
Which type of voice mode is often used for long-distance (weak signal) contacts on the VHF and UHF bands?
Which type of modulation is commonly used for VHF and UHF voice repeaters?
Which of the following types of signal has the narrowest bandwidth?
Which sideband is normally used for 10 meter HF, VHF, and UHF single-sideband communications?
What is a characteristic of single sideband (SSB) compared to FM?
What is the approximate bandwidth of a typical single sideband (SSB) voice signal?
What is the approximate bandwidth of a VHF repeater FM voice signal?
What is the approximate bandwidth of AM fast-scan TV transmissions?
What is the approximate bandwidth required to transmit a CW signal?
Which of the following is a disadvantage of FM compared with single sideband?
Technician.answer: Only one signal can be received at a time

Technician.question: What telemetry information is typically transmitted by satellite beacons?
Technician.answer: Health and status of the satellite

Technician.question: What is the impact of using excessive effective radiated power on a satellite uplink?
Which of the following are provided by satellite tracking programs?
What mode of transmission is commonly used by amateur radio satellites?
What is a satellite beacon?
Technician.answer: A transmission from a satellite that contains status information

Technician.question: Which of the following are inputs to a satellite tracking program?
What is Doppler shift in reference to satellite communications?
Technician.answer: An observed change in signal frequency caused by relative motion between the satellite and Earth station

Technician.question: What is meant by the statement that a satellite is operating in U/V mode?
Technician.answer: The satellite uplink is in the 70 centimeter band and the downlink is in the 2 meter band

Technician.question: What causes spin fading of satellite signals?
Technician.answer: Rotation of the satellite and its antennas

Technician.question: What is a LEO satellite?
Technician.answer: A satellite in low earth orbit

Technician.question: Who may receive telemetry from a space station?
Which of the following is a way to determine whether your satellite uplink power is neither too low nor too high?
Technician.answer: Your signal strength on the downlink should be about the same as the beacon

Technician.question: Which of the following methods is used to locate sources of noise interference or jamming?
Which of these items would be useful for a hidden transmitter hunt?
What operating activity involves contacting as many stations as possible during a specified period?
Which of the following is good procedure when contacting another station in a contest?
Technician.answer: Send only the minimum information needed for proper identification and the contest exchange

Technician.question: What is a grid locator?
Technician.answer: A letter-number designator assigned to a geographic location

Technician.question: How is over the air access to IRLP nodes accomplished?
What is Voice Over Internet Protocol (VoIP)?
Technician.answer: A method of delivering voice communications over the internet using digital techniques

Technician.question: What is the Internet Radio Linking Project (IRLP)?
Technician.answer: A technique to connect amateur radio systems, such as repeaters, via the internet using Voice Over Internet Protocol (VoIP)

Technician.question: Which of the following protocols enables an amateur station to transmit through a repeater without using a radio to initiate the transmission?
What is required before using the EchoLink system?
Technician.answer: Register your call sign and provide proof of license

Technician.question: What is an amateur radio station that connects other amateur stations to the internet?
Which of the following is a digital communications mode?
What is a “talkgroup” on a DMR repeater?
Technician.answer: A way for groups of users to share a channel at different times without hearing other users on the channel

Technician.question: What kind of data can be transmitted by APRS?
What type of transmission is indicated by the term "NTSC?"
Technician.answer: An analog fast-scan color TV signal

Technician.question: Which of the following is an application of APRS?
Technician.answer: Providing real-time tactical digital communications in conjunction with a map showing the locations of stations

Technician.question: What does the abbreviation "PSK" mean?
Which of the following describes DMR?
Technician.answer: A technique for time-multiplexing two digital voice signals on a single 12.5 kHz repeater channel

Technician.question: Which of the following is included in packet radio transmissions?
What is CW?
Technician.answer: Another name for a Morse code transmission

Technician.question: Which of the following operating activities is supported by digital mode software in the WSJT-X software suite?
What is an ARQ transmission system?
Technician.answer: An error correction method in which the receiving station detects errors and sends a request for retransmission

Technician.question: Which of the following best describes an amateur radio mesh network?
Technician.answer: An amateur-radio based data network using commercial Wi-Fi equipment with modified firmware

Technician.question: What is FT8?
Technician.answer: A digital mode capable of low signal-to-noise operation

Technician.question: What is a beam antenna?
Technician.answer: An antenna that concentrates signals in one direction

Technician.question: Which of the following describes a type of antenna loading?
Technician.answer: Electrically lengthening by inserting inductors in radiating elements

Technician.question: Which of the following describes a simple dipole oriented parallel to Earth's surface?
What is a disadvantage of the short, flexible antenna supplied with most handheld radio transceivers, compared to a full-sized quarter-wave antenna?
Which of the following increases the resonant frequency of a dipole antenna?
Which of the following types of antenna offers the greatest gain?
What is a disadvantage of using a handheld VHF transceiver with a flexible antenna inside a vehicle?
Technician.answer: Signal strength is reduced due to the shielding effect of the vehicle

Technician.question: What is the approximate length, in inches, of a quarter-wavelength vertical antenna for 146 MHz?
What is the approximate length, in inches, of a half-wavelength 6 meter dipole antenna?
In which direction does a half-wave dipole antenna radiate the strongest signal?
What is antenna gain?
Technician.answer: The increase in signal strength in a specified direction compared to a reference antenna

Technician.question: What is an advantage of a 5/8 wavelength whip antenna for VHF or UHF mobile service?
Technician.answer: It has more gain than a 1/4-wavelength antenna

Technician.question: What is a benefit of low SWR?
What is the most common impedance of coaxial cables used in amateur radio?
Why is coaxial cable the most common feed line for amateur radio antenna systems?
Technician.answer: It is easy to use and requires few special installation considerations

Technician.question: What is the major function of an antenna tuner (antenna coupler)?
Technician.answer: It matches the antenna system impedance to the transceiver's output impedance

Technician.question: What happens as the frequency of a signal in coaxial cable is increased?
Which of the following RF connector types is most suitable for frequencies above 400 MHz?
Which of the following is true of PL-259 type coax connectors?
Technician.answer: They are commonly used at HF and VHF frequencies

Technician.question: Which of the following is a source of loss in coaxial feed line?
What can cause erratic changes in SWR?
Technician.answer: Loose connection in the antenna or feed line

Technician.question: What is the electrical difference between RG-58 and RG-213 coaxial cable?
Technician.answer: RG-213 cable has less loss at a given frequency

Technician.question: Which of the following types of feed line has the lowest loss at VHF and UHF?
What is standing wave ratio (SWR)?
Technician.answer: A measure of how well a load is matched to a transmission line

Technician.question: Which of the following is a safety hazard of a 12-volt storage battery?
Technician.answer: Shorting the terminals can cause burns, fire, or an explosion

Technician.question: What health hazard is presented by electrical current flowing through the body?
In the United States, what circuit does black wire insulation indicate in a three-wire 120 V cable?
What is the purpose of a fuse in an electrical circuit?
Technician.answer: To remove power in case of overload

Technician.question: Why should a 5-ampere fuse never be replaced with a 20-ampere fuse?
Technician.answer: Excessive current could cause a fire

Technician.question: What is a good way to guard against electrical shock at your station?
Where should a lightning arrester be installed in a coaxial feed line?
Technician.answer: On a grounded panel near where feed lines enter the building

Technician.question: Where should a fuse or circuit breaker be installed in a 120V AC power circuit?
Technician.answer: In series with the hot conductor only

Technician.question: What should be done to all external ground rods or earth connections?
Technician.answer: Bond them together with heavy wire or conductive strap

Technician.question: What hazard is caused by charging or discharging a battery too quickly?
What hazard exists in a power supply immediately after turning it off?
Which of the following precautions should be taken when measuring high voltages with a voltmeter?
Technician.answer: Ensure that the voltmeter and leads are rated for use at the voltages to be measured

Technician.question: Which of the following is good practice when installing ground wires on a tower for lightning protection?
Technician.answer: Ensure that connections are short and direct

Technician.question: What is required when climbing an antenna tower?
Under what circumstances is it safe to climb a tower without a helper or observer?
Which of the following is an important safety precaution to observe when putting up an antenna tower?
Technician.answer: Look for and stay clear of any overhead electrical wires

Technician.question: What is the purpose of a safety wire through a turnbuckle used to tension guy lines?
Technician.answer: Prevent loosening of the turnbuckle from vibration

Technician.question: What is the minimum safe distance from a power line to allow when installing an antenna?
Technician.answer: Enough so that if the antenna falls, no part of it can come closer than 10 feet to the power wires

Technician.question: Which of the following is an important safety rule to remember when using a crank-up tower?
Technician.answer: This type of tower must not be climbed unless it is retracted, or mechanical safety locking devices have been installed

Technician.question: Which is a proper grounding method for a tower?
Technician.answer: Separate eight-foot ground rods for each tower leg, bonded to the tower and each other

Technician.question: Why should you avoid attaching an antenna to a utility pole?
Technician.answer: The antenna could contact high-voltage power lines

Technician.question: Which of the following is true when installing grounding conductors used for lightning protection?
Which of the following establishes grounding requirements for an amateur radio tower or antenna?
What type of radiation are radio signals?
At which of the following frequencies does maximum permissible exposure have the lowest value?
How does the allowable power density for RF safety change if duty cycle changes from 100 percent to 50 percent?
Technician.answer: It increases by a factor of 2

Technician.question: What factors affect the RF exposure of people near an amateur station antenna?
Why do exposure limits vary with frequency?
Technician.answer: The human body absorbs more RF energy at some frequencies than at others

Technician.question: Which of the following is an acceptable method to determine whether your station complies with FCC RF exposure regulations?
What hazard is created by touching an antenna during a transmission?
Which of the following actions can reduce exposure to RF radiation?
How can you make sure your station stays in compliance with RF safety regulations?
Technician.answer: By re-evaluating the station whenever an item in the transmitter or antenna system is changed

Technician.question: Why is duty cycle one of the factors used to determine safe RF radiation exposure levels?
Technician.answer: It affects the average exposure to radiation

Technician.question: What is the definition of duty cycle during the averaging time for RF exposure?
Technician.answer: The percentage of time that a transmitter is transmitting

Technician.question: How does RF radiation differ from ionizing radiation (radioactivity)?
Technician.answer: RF radiation does not have sufficient energy to cause chemical changes in cells and damage DNA

Technician.question: Who is responsible for ensuring that no person is exposed to RF energy above the FCC exposure limits?

General.question: On which HF and/or MF amateur bands are there portions where General class licensees cannot transmit?
General.answer: 80 meters, 40 meters, 20 meters, and 15 meters

General.question: On which of the following bands is phone operation prohibited?
General.answer: 30 Meters

General.question: On which of the following bands is image transmission prohibited?
General.answer: 30 Meters

General.question: Which of the following amateur bands is restricted to communication only on specific channels, rather than frequency ranges?
General.answer: 60 Meters

General.question: On which of the following frequencies are General class licensees prohibited from operating as control operator?
General.answer: 7.125 MHz to 7.175 MHz

General.question: Which of the following applies when the FCC rules designate the amateur service as a secondary user on a band?
General.answer: Amateur stations must not cause harmful interference to primary users and must accept interference from primary users

General.question: On which amateur frequencies in the 10-meter band may stations with a General class control operator transmit CW emissions?
General.answer: The entire band

General.question: Which HF bands have segments exclusively allocated to Amateur Extra licensees?
General.answer: 80 meters, 40 meters, 20 meters, and 15 meters

General.question: Which of the following frequencies is within the General class portion of the 15-meter band?
What portion of the 10-meter band is available for repeater use?
General.answer: The portion above 29.5 MHz

General.question: When General class licensees are not permitted to use the entire voice portion of a band, which portion of the voice segment is available to them?
General.answer: The upper frequency portion

General.question: What is the maximum height above ground for an antenna structure not near a public use airport without requiring notification to the FAA and registration with the FCC?
General.answer: 200 Feet

General.question: With which of the following conditions must beacon stations comply?
General.answer: No more than one beacon station may transmit in the same band from the same station location

General.question: Which of the following is a purpose of a beacon station as identified in the FCC rules?
General.answer: Observation of propagation and reception

General.question: Which of the following transmissions is permitted for all amateur stations?
General.answer: Occasional retransmission of weather and propagation forecast information from US government stations

General.question: Which of the following one-way transmissions are permitted?
General.answer: Transmissions to assist with learning the International Morse code

General.question: Under what conditions are state and local governments permitted to regulate amateur radio antenna structures?
General.answer: Amateur Service communications must be reasonably accommodated, and regulations must constitute the minimum practical to accommodate a legitimate purpose of the state or local entity

General.question: What are the restrictions on the use of abbreviations or procedural signals in the amateur service?
General.answer: They may be used if they do not obscure the meaning of a message

General.question: When is it permissible to communicate with amateur stations in countries outside the areas administered by the Federal Communications Commission?
General.answer: When the contact is with amateurs in any country except those whose administrations have notified the ITU that they object to such communications

General.question: On what HF frequencies are automatically controlled beacons permitted?
General.answer: 28.20 MHz to 28.30 MHz

General.question: What is the power limit for beacon stations?
General.answer: 100 watts PEP output

General.question: Who or what determines “good engineering and good amateur practice,” as applied to the operation of an amateur station in all respects not covered by the Part 97 rules?
General.answer: The FCC

General.question: What is the maximum transmitter power an amateur station may use on 10.140 MHz?
General.answer: 200 watts PEP output

General.question: What is the maximum transmitter power an amateur station may use on the 12-meter band?
General.answer: 1500 Watts PEP output

General.question: What is the maximum bandwidth permitted by FCC rules for amateur radio stations transmitting on USB frequencies in the 60-meter band?
General.answer: 2.8kHz

General.question: Which of the following is required by the FCC rules when operating in the 60-meter band?
General.answer: If you are using an antenna other than a dipole, you must keep a record of the gain of your antenna

General.question: What is the limit for transmitter power on the 28 MHz band for a General Class control operator?
General.answer: 1500 watts PEP output

General.question: What is the limit for transmitter power on the 1.8 MHz band?
General.answer: 1500 watts PEP output

General.question: What must be done before using a new digital protocol on the air?
General.answer: Publicly document the technical characteristics of the protocol

General.question: What is the maximum power limit on the 60-meter band?
General.answer: ERP of 100 watts PEP with respect to a dipole

General.question: What measurement is specified by FCC rules that regulate maximum power?
General.answer: PEP output from the transmitter

General.question: Who may receive partial credit for the elements represented by an expired amateur radio license?
General.answer: Any person who can demonstrate that they once held an FCC-issued General, Advanced, or Amateur Extra class license that was not revoked by the FCC

General.question: What license examinations may you administer as an accredited Volunteer Examiner holding a General class operator license?
General.answer: Technician only

General.question: On which of the following band segments may you operate if you are a Technician class operator and have an unexpired Certificate of Successful Completion of Examination (CSCE) for General class privileges?
General.answer: On any General or Technician class band segment

General.question: Who must observe the administration of a Technician class license examination?
General.answer: At least three Volunteer Examiners of General class or higher

General.question: When operating a US station by remote control from outside the country, what license is required of the control operator?
General.answer: A US operator/primary station license

General.question: Until an upgrade to General class is shown in the FCC database, when must a Technician licensee identify with “AG” after their call sign?
General.answer: Whenever they operate using General class frequency privileges

General.question: Volunteer Examiners are accredited by what organization?
General.answer: A Volunteer Examiner Coordinator

General.question: Which of the following criteria must be met for a non-US citizen to be an accredited Volunteer Examiner?
General.answer: The person must hold an FCC granted amateur radio license of General class or above

General.question: How long is a Certificate of Successful Completion of Examination (CSCE) valid for exam element credit?
General.answer: 365 Days

General.question: What is the minimum age that one must be to qualify as an accredited Volunteer Examiner?
General.answer: 18 years

General.question: What action is required to obtain a new General class license after a previously held license has expired and the two-year grace period has passed?
General.answer: The applicant must show proof of the appropriate expired license grant and pass the current Element 2 exam

General.question: When operating a station in South America by remote control over the internet from the US, what regulations apply?
General.answer: Only those of the remote station's country

General.question: Which of the following would disqualify a third party from participating in sending a message via an amateur station?
General.answer: The third party's amateur license has been revoked and not reinstated

General.question: When may a 10-meter repeater retransmit the 2-meter signal from a station that has a Technician class control operator?
General.answer: Only if the 10-meter repeater control operator holds at least a General class license

General.question: What is required to conduct communications with a digital station operating under automatic control outside the automatic control band segments?
General.answer: The station initiating the contact must be under local or remote control

General.question: Which of the following conditions require a licensed amateur radio operator to take specific steps to avoid harmful interference to other users or facilities?
General.answer: All these choices are correct

General.question: What are the restrictions on messages sent to a third party in a country with which there is a Third-Party Agreement?
General.answer: They must relate to amateur radio, or remarks of a personal character, or messages relating to emergencies or disaster relief

General.question: The frequency allocations of which ITU region apply to radio amateurs operating in North and South America?
General.answer: Region 2

General.question: In what part of the 2.4 GHz band may an amateur station communicate with non-licensed Wi-Fi stations?
General.answer: No Part

General.question: What is the maximum PEP output allowed for spread spectrum transmissions?
General.answer: 10 Watts

General.question: Under what circumstances are messages that are sent via digital modes exempt from Part 97 third-party rules that apply to other modes of communication?
General.answer: Under No Circumstances

General.question: Why should an amateur operator normally avoid transmitting on 14.100, 18.110, 21.150, 24.930 and 28.200 MHz?
General.answer: A system of propagation beacon stations operates on those frequencies

General.question: On what bands may automatically controlled stations transmitting RTTY or data emissions communicate with other automatically controlled digital stations?
General.answer: Anywhere in the 6-meter or shorter wavelength bands, and in limited segments of some of the HF bands

General.question: When may third-party messages be transmitted via remote control?
General.answer: Under any circumstances in which third party messages are permitted by FCC rules

General.question: Which mode is most commonly used for voice communications on frequencies of 14 MHz or higher?
General.answer: Upper sideband

General.question: Which mode is most commonly used for voice communications on the 160-, 75-, and 40-meter bands?
General.answer: Lower sideband

General.question: Which mode is most commonly used for SSB voice communications in the VHF and UHF bands?
General.answer: Upper sideband

General.question: Which mode is most commonly used for voice communications on the 17- and 12-meter bands?
General.answer: Upper sideband

General.question: Which mode of voice communication is most commonly used on the HF amateur bands?
General.answer: Single sideband

General.question: Which of the following is an advantage of using single sideband, as compared to other analog voice modes on the HF amateur bands?
General.answer: Less bandwidth used and greater power efficiency

General.question: Which of the following statements is true of single sideband SSB?
General.answer: Only one sideband is transmitted; the other sideband and carrier are suppressed

General.question: What is the recommended way to break into a phone contact?
General.answer: Say your call sign once

General.question: Why do most amateur stations use lower sideband on the 160-, 75-, and 40-meter bands?
General.answer: It is commonly accepted amateur practice

General.question: Which of the following statements is true of VOX operation versus PTT operation?
General.answer: It allows “hands free” operation

General.question: Generally, who should respond to a station in the contiguous 48 states calling “CQ DX”?
General.answer: Any stations outside the lower 48 states

General.question: What control is typically adjusted for proper ALC setting on a single sideband transceiver?
General.answer: Transmit audio or microphone gain

General.question: Which of the following is true concerning access to frequencies?
General.answer: Except during emergencies, no amateur station has priority access to any frequency

General.question: What is the first thing you should do if you are communicating with another amateur station and hear a station in distress break in?
General.answer: Acknowledge the station in distress and determine what assistance may be needed

General.question: What is good amateur practice if propagation changes during a contact creating interference from other stations using the frequency?
General.answer: Attempt to resolve the interference problem with the other stations in a mutually acceptable manner

General.question: When selecting a CW transmitting frequency, what minimum separation from other stations should be used to minimize interference to stations on adjacent frequencies?
General.answer: 150 Hz to 500 Hz

General.question: When selecting an SSB transmitting frequency, what minimum separation should be used to minimize interference to stations on adjacent frequencies?
General.answer: 2 kHz to 3 kHz

General.question: How can you avoid harmful interference on an apparently clear frequency before calling CQ on CW or phone?
General.answer: Send “QRL?” on CW, followed by your call sign; or, if using phone, ask if the frequency is in use, followed by your call sign

General.question: Which of the following complies with commonly accepted amateur practice when choosing a frequency on which to initiate a call?
General.answer: Follow the voluntary band plan

General.question: What is the voluntary band plan restriction for US stations transmitting within the 48 contiguous states in the 50.1 MHz to 50.125 MHz band segment?
General.answer: Only contacts with stations not within the 48 contiguous states

General.question: Who may be the control operator of an amateur station transmitting in RACES to assist relief operations during a disaster?
General.answer: Only a person holding an FCC-issued amateur operator license

General.question: Which of the following is good amateur practice for net management?
General.answer: Have a backup frequency in case of interference or poor conditions

General.question: How often may RACES training drills and tests be routinely conducted without special authorization?
General.answer: No more than 1 hour per week

General.question: Which of the following describes full break in CW operation QSK ?
General.answer: Transmitting stations can receive between code characters and elements

General.question: What should you do if a CW station sends QRS ?
General.answer: Send slower

General.question: What does it mean when a CW operator sends KN at the end of a transmission?
General.answer: Listening only for a specific station or stations

General.question: What does the Q signal QRL mean?
General.answer: Are you busy or Is this frequency in use

General.question: What is the best speed to use when answering a CQ in Morse code?
General.answer: The fastest speed at which you are comfortable copying, but no faster than the CQ

General.question: What does the term zero beat mean in CW operation?
General.answer: Matching the transmit frequency to the frequency of a received signal

General.question: When sending CW what does a C mean when added to the RST report?
General.answer: Chirpy or unstable signal

General.question: What prosign is sent to indicate the end of a formal message when using CW?
General.answer: AR

General.question: What does the Q signal QSL mean?
General.answer: I have received and understood

General.question: What does the Q signal QRN mean?
General.answer: I am troubled by static

General.question: What does the Q signal QRV mean?
General.answer: I am ready to receive

General.question: What is the Volunteer Monitor Program?
General.answer: Amateur volunteers who are formally enlisted to monitor the airwaves for rules violations

General.question: Which of the following are objectives of the Volunteer Monitor Program?
General.answer: To encourage amateur radio operators to self-regulate and comply with the rules

General.question: What procedure may be used by Volunteer Monitors to localize a station whose continuous carrier is holding a repeater on in their area?
General.answer: Compare beam headings on the repeater input from their home locations with that of other Volunteer Monitors

General.question: Which of the following describes an azimuthal projection map?
General.answer: A map that shows true bearings and distances from a specific location

General.question: Which of the following indicates that you are looking for an HF contact with any station?
General.answer: Repeat “CQ” a few times, followed by “this is,” then your call sign a few times, then pause to listen, repeat as necessary

General.question: How is a directional antenna pointed when making a “long-path” contact with another station?
General.answer: 180 degrees from the station's short-path heading

General.question: Which of the following are examples of the NATO Phonetic Alphabet?
General.answer: Alpha, Bravo, Charlie, Delta

General.question: Why do many amateurs keep a station log?
General.answer: To help with a reply if the FCC requests information about your station

General.question: Which of the following is required when participating in a contest on HF frequencies?
General.answer: Identify your station according to normal FCC regulations

General.question: What is QRP operation?
General.answer: Low-power transmit operation

General.question: Why are signal reports typically exchanged at the beginning of an HF contact?
General.answer: To allow each station to operate according to conditions

General.question: Which mode is normally used when sending RTTY signals via AFSK with an SSB transmitter?
General.answer: LSB

General.question: What is VARA?
General.answer: A digital protocol used with Winlink

General.question: What symptoms may result from other signals interfering with a PACTOR or VARA transmission?
General.answer: All these choices are correct

General.question: Which of the following is good practice when choosing a transmitting frequency to answer a station calling CQ using FT8?
General.answer: Find a clear frequency during the alternate time slot to the calling station

General.question: What is the standard sideband for JT65 JT9 FT4 or FT8 digital signal when using AFSK?
General.answer: USB

General.question: What is the most common frequency shift for RTTY emissions in the amateur HF bands?
General.answer: 170 Hz

General.question: Which of the following is required when using FT8?
General.answer: Computer time accurate to within approximately 1 second

General.question: In what segment of the 20-meter band are most digital mode operations commonly found?
General.answer: Between 14.070 MHz and 14.100 MHz

General.question: How do you join a contact between two stations using the PACTOR protocol?
General.answer: Joining an existing contact is not possible, PACTOR connections are limited to two stations

General.question: Which of the following is a way to establish contact with a digital messaging system gateway station?
General.answer: Transmit a connect message on the station’s published frequency

General.question: What is the primary purpose of an Amateur Radio Emergency Data Network (AREDN) mesh network?
General.answer: To provide high-speed data services during an emergency or community event

General.question: Which of the following describes Winlink?
General.answer: All these choices are correct

General.question: What is another name for a Winlink Remote Message Server?
General.answer: Gateway

General.question: What could be wrong if you cannot decode an RTTY or other FSK signal even though it is apparently tuned in properly?
General.answer: All these choices are correct

General.question: Which of the following is a common location for FT8?
General.answer: Approximately 14.074 MHz to 14.077 MHz

General.question: How does a higher sunspot number affect HF propagation?
General.answer: Higher sunspot numbers generally indicate a greater probability of good propagation at higher frequencies

General.question: What effect does a sudden ionospheric disturbance have on the daytime ionospheric propagation?
General.answer: It disrupts signals on lower frequencies more than those on higher frequencies

General.question: Approximately how long does it take the increased ultraviolet and X-ray radiation from a solar flare to affect radio propagation on Earth?
General.answer: 8 Minutes

General.question: Which of the following are the least reliable bands for long-distance communications during periods of low solar activity?
General.answer: 15 meters, 12 meters, and 10 meters

General.question: What is the solar flux index?
General.answer: A measure of solar radiation with a wavelength of 10.7 centimeters

General.question: What is a geomagnetic storm?
General.answer: A temporary disturbance in Earth's geomagnetic field

General.question: At what point in the solar cycle does the 20-meter band usually support worldwide propagation during daylight hours?
General.answer: At any point

General.question: How can a geomagnetic storm affect HF propagation?
General.answer: Degrade high-latitude HF propagation

General.question: How can high geomagnetic activity benefit radio communications?
General.answer: Creates auroras that can reflect VHF signals

General.question: What causes HF propagation conditions to vary periodically in a 26- to 28-day cycle?
General.answer: Rotation of the Sun's surface layers around its axis

General.question: How long does it take a coronal mass ejection to affect radio propagation on Earth?
General.answer: 15 Hours to several days

General.question: What does the K-index measure?
General.answer: The short-term stability of Earth's geomagnetic field

General.question: What does the A-index measure?
General.answer: The long-term stability of Earth's geomagnetic field

General.question: How is long distance radio communication usually affected by the charged particles that reach Earth from solar coronal holes?
General.answer: HF communication is disturbed

General.question: What is a characteristic of skywave signals arriving at your location by both short-path and long-path propagation?
General.answer: A slightly delayed echo might be heard

General.question: What factors affect the MUF?
General.answer: All these choices are correct

General.question: Which frequency will have the least attenuation for long distance skip propagation?
General.answer: Just below the MUF

General.question: Which of the following is a way to determine current propagation on a desired band from your station?
General.answer: Use a network of automated receiving stations on the internet to see where your transmissions are being received

General.question: How does the ionosphere affect radio waves with frequencies below the MUF and above the LUF?
General.answer: They are refracted back to Earth

General.question: What usually happens to radio waves with frequencies below the LUF?
General.answer: They are attenuated before reaching the destination

General.question: What does LUF stand for?
General.answer: The Lowest Usable Frequency for communications between two specific points

General.question: What does MUF stand for?
General.answer: The Maximum Usable Frequency for communications between two points

General.question: What is the approximate maximum distance along the Earth's surface normally covered in one hop using the F2 region?
General.answer: 2,500 Miles

General.question: What is the approximate maximum distance along the Earth's surface normally covered in one hop using the E region?
General.answer: 1,200 Miles

General.question: What happens to HF propagation when the LUF exceeds the MUF?
General.answer: Propagation via ordinary skywave communications is not possible over that path

General.question: Which of the following is typical of the lower HF frequencies during the summer?
General.answer: High levels of atmospheric noise or static

General.question: Which ionospheric region is closest to the surface of Earth?
General.answer: The D region

General.question: What is meant by the term critical frequency at a given incidence angle?
General.answer: The highest frequency which is refracted back to Earth

General.question: Why is skip propagation via the F2 region longer than that via the other ionospheric regions?
General.answer: Because it is the highest

General.question: What does the term critical angle mean, as applied to radio wave propagation?
General.answer: The highest takeoff angle that will return a radio wave to Earth under specific ionospheric conditions

General.question: Why is long distance communication on the 40- 60- 80- and 160 meter bands more difficult during the day?
General.answer: The D region absorbs signals at these frequencies during daylight hours

General.question: What is a characteristic of HF scatter?
General.answer: Signals have a fluttering sound

General.question: What makes HF scatter signals often sound distorted?
General.answer: Energy is scattered into the skip zone through several different paths

General.question: Why are HF scatter signals in the skip zone usually weak?
General.answer: Only a small part of the signal energy is scattered into the skip zone

General.question: What type of propagation allows signals to be heard in the transmitting station's skip zone?
General.answer: Scatter

General.question: What is near vertical incidence skywave NVIS propagation?
General.answer: Short distance MF or HF propagation at high elevation angles

General.question: Which ionospheric region is the most absorbent of signals below 10 MHz during daylight hours?
General.answer: The D region

General.question: G4A
General.answer: next section
